action.action-desc: Mr. Nadler introduced the following bill; which was referred to the Committee on the Judiciary

form.official-title: To amend the Immigration and Nationality Act to exempt certain elderly persons from demonstrating an understanding of the English language and the history, principles, and form of government of the United States as a requirement for naturalization, and to permit certain other elderly persons to take the history and government examination in a language of their choice.

section.text:
This Act may be cited as the
Senior Citizenship Act of 2013 .

section.header: Fulfillment by elderly persons of requirement for naturalization relating to knowledge of English language
section.text: Section 312(b)(2) of the Immigration and Nationality Act ( 8 U.S.C. 1423(b)(2) ) is amended—

paragraph.text: by adding at the end the following:

subclause.text: is over sixty-five years of age and has been living in the United States for periods totaling at least five years subsequent to a lawful admission for permanent residence.

section.header: Fulfillment by elderly persons of requirement for naturalization relating to knowledge of Government of the United States
section.text: Section 312(b)(3) of the Immigration and Nationality Act (8 U.S.C. 1423(b)(3)) is amended—

paragraph.text:
by striking Attorney General each place such term appears and inserting
Secretary of Homeland Security ;
by adding at the end the following:

subparagraph.text: In the case of a person who, on the date of the filing of the person’s application for naturalization, as provided in section 334, is over sixty-five years of age and has been living in the United States for periods totaling at least five years subsequent to a lawful admission for permanent residence, the Secretary of Homeland Security shall permit the person to fulfill the requirement of subsection (a)(2) through an examination in a language other than English selected by the person.

In the case of a person who, on the date of the filing of the person’s application for naturalization, as provided in section 334, is over seventy-five years of age and has been living in the United States for periods totaling at least five years subsequent to a lawful admission for permanent residence, the requirement of subsection (a)(2) shall not apply.

section.text: The amendments made by this Act shall take effect on the date of the enactment of this Act and shall apply to applications for naturalization pending on or after such date.
